questions.question: The research and development (R&D) tax credit under Section 41 applies to qualified research expenses. Which of the following is a component of the regular credit calculation?

options.B: 20% of qualified research expenses over a base amount
options.C: 100% of research expenses up to $1 million
options.D: 50% of research expenses exceeding prior year

questions.explanation: The regular R&D credit is 20% of qualified research expenses (QREs) that exceed a base amount calculated using historical research spending relative to gross receipts. There is also a 14% alternative simplified credit.
questions.tip: R&D credit: 20% of QREs over base amount (regular) or 14% simplified method.

questions.question: For 2024, what is the maximum child tax credit per qualifying child under age 17?
questions.explanation: The child tax credit is $2,000 per qualifying child under age 17 for 2024. Up to $1,700 may be refundable as the additional child tax credit. The credit phases out at higher income levels.
questions.tip: Child tax credit: $2,000 per child under 17, up to $1,700 refundable.

questions.question: Which education credit can be claimed for an unlimited number of years for the same student?
questions.explanation: The Lifetime Learning Credit has no limit on the number of years it can be claimed. The American Opportunity Credit is limited to 4 tax years per student for undergraduate education.
questions.tip: Lifetime Learning = unlimited years; American Opportunity = max 4 years.

questions.question: A taxpayer paid $5,000 in foreign income taxes on $20,000 of foreign source income. The taxpayer's U.S. tax on this income would be $4,400 (22% bracket). What is the maximum foreign tax credit?
questions.explanation: The foreign tax credit is limited to the U.S. tax attributable to foreign source income. Even though $5,000 was paid, the credit is limited to $4,400 (the U.S. tax). The excess $600 can be carried back 1 year or forward 10 years.
questions.tip: FTC limited to U.S. tax on foreign income. Excess can be carried over.

questions.question: Which of the following disqualifies a taxpayer from claiming the earned income credit?
questions.explanation: Investment income exceeding the threshold ($11,000 for 2024) disqualifies a taxpayer from the EIC. Self-employment income qualifies as earned income, head of household is a valid filing status, and childless taxpayers may qualify for a smaller credit.
questions.tip: EIC disqualifier: Investment income over threshold (adjusted annually).

questions.question: The general business credit combines multiple credits into one. What happens if the credit exceeds the limitation in the current year?

options.B: The excess is carried back 1 year, then forward 20 years
options.C: The excess converts to a refund
options.D: The excess is carried forward only, for 5 years

questions.explanation: General business credit carrybacks go back 1 year, and carryforwards extend 20 years. Credits are applied in chronological order. Some credits (like R&D) have special rules for startups.
questions.tip: General business credit: 1 year back, 20 years forward carryover.

questions.question: A homeowner installs a qualifying solar electric system in 2024 for $30,000. What is the residential clean energy credit?
questions.explanation: The residential clean energy credit (formerly residential energy efficient property credit) is 30% of qualified expenditures for solar electric, solar water heating, fuel cells, small wind, geothermal heat pumps, and battery storage through 2032.
questions.tip: Residential solar credit: 30% through 2032, then phases down.

questions.question: An employer hires a qualified veteran and pays $12,000 in first-year wages. What is the maximum work opportunity tax credit for this hire?
questions.explanation: For most target groups, WOTC is 40% of qualified first-year wages up to $6,000 ($2,400 max). For certain veterans, the credit can be 40% of up to $24,000 ($9,600 max). The standard $12,000 in wages for a qualified veteran yields $4,800 to $9,600 depending on veteran category.
questions.tip: WOTC: 40% of qualified wages; caps vary by target group (higher for veterans).

questions.question: Which expense qualifies for the Section 41 research credit?

options.A: Marketing research for new product launch
options.B: Wages for engineers developing new manufacturing process
options.C: Research conducted outside the United States
options.D: Adaptation of existing product for specific customer

questions.explanation: Qualified research expenses include wages for employees performing qualified research activities, supplies used in research, and contract research expenses. Research must be technological in nature and involve uncertainty. Marketing research, foreign research, and customer adaptation generally don't qualify.
questions.tip: R&D credit requires: technological uncertainty, experimentation process, permitted purpose.

questions.question: A taxpayer spends $500,000 on qualified rehabilitation expenditures for a certified historic structure. The credit must be taken ratably over what period?
questions.explanation: The 20% rehabilitation credit for certified historic structures must be claimed ratably over 5 years beginning in the year the property is placed in service. For $500,000 in expenditures, the total credit is $100,000 ($20,000 per year for 5 years).
questions.tip: Historic rehabilitation credit: 20% of QREs, claimed over 5 years.

questions.question: A developer receives a $2 million allocation of low-income housing tax credits (LIHTC). How long is the credit period?
questions.explanation: LIHTC provides credits over a 10-year credit period. The property must remain in compliance for a 15-year compliance period plus an extended use period. The credit is approximately 9% (new construction) or 4% (acquisition/rehabilitation) of qualified basis annually.
questions.tip: LIHTC: 10-year credit period; 15-year initial compliance period.

questions.question: A small business with $800,000 in gross receipts and 20 employees spends $8,000 on ADA accessibility improvements. What is the disabled access credit?
questions.explanation: The disabled access credit is 50% of eligible expenditures between $250 and $10,250 (max credit $5,000). For $8,000 spent: ($8,000 - $250) × 50% = $3,875. However, eligible expenditures cap at $10,250, so: ($8,000 - $250) × 50% = $3,875. The answer is $3,750 using the formula correctly.
questions.tip: Disabled access credit: 50% × (expenditures between $250 and $10,250).

questions.question: For the clean vehicle credit under Section 30D, which requirement must a new electric vehicle meet to qualify for the full $7,500 credit?

options.A: Final assembly in North America only
options.B: Battery component and critical mineral sourcing requirements
options.D: Manufacturer has sold fewer than 200,000 vehicles

questions.explanation: The IRA restructured the credit into two $3,750 components: one for meeting battery component requirements (assembly in North America) and one for critical mineral requirements (sourcing from US or free trade partners). Both requirements must be met for the full $7,500.
questions.tip: EV credit: $3,750 for battery components + $3,750 for critical minerals = $7,500 max.

questions.question: A small employer with 8 employees and average annual wages of $25,000 provides health insurance. What is the maximum credit percentage for coverage purchased through the SHOP marketplace?
questions.explanation: Small employers with fewer than 25 full-time equivalent employees and average wages below $56,000 (indexed) can claim up to 50% of premiums paid for coverage purchased through the SHOP marketplace (35% for tax-exempt employers).
questions.tip: Small employer health credit: Up to 50% of premiums (SHOP marketplace required for max credit).

questions.question: An investor makes a $1 million qualified equity investment in a Community Development Entity (CDE) for the new markets tax credit. What is the total credit over the 7-year credit period?
questions.explanation: NMTC provides a 39% credit over 7 years: 5% in years 1-3 (15% total) and 6% in years 4-7 (24% total). For a $1 million investment: $1M × 39% = $390,000 total credit.
questions.tip: NMTC: 5% × 3 years + 6% × 4 years = 39% total over 7 years.

questions.question: A startup company with $3 million in gross receipts generates $40,000 in R&D credits but has no income tax liability. Under Section 41, what can the startup elect?

options.B: Offset against payroll tax liability up to $500,000
options.D: Sale of credits to another taxpayer

questions.explanation: Qualified small businesses (under $5M gross receipts, no more than 5 years of gross receipts) can elect to apply up to $500,000 of R&D credit against payroll tax liability. This provides immediate benefit when the company has no income tax liability.
questions.tip: Startup R&D credit: Offset payroll tax (up to $500K) if <$5M gross receipts.

questions.question: A taxpayer received $6,000 in advance premium tax credits during 2024 based on estimated income. Actual income resulted in a credit of only $4,500. What happens at tax filing?

options.C: The excess converts to a penalty
options.D: The taxpayer's health coverage is retroactively cancelled

questions.explanation: Excess advance premium tax credits must be repaid when filing the tax return, subject to repayment caps based on household income (ranging from $350 to $3,000 for individuals, or unlimited above 400% FPL). Here, $1,500 would be added to tax liability.
questions.tip: Excess advance PTC: Repay at filing, subject to income-based caps.

questions.question: A taxpayer incurs $10,000 of qualified adoption expenses in 2023 and the adoption becomes final in 2024. When is the credit claimed?
questions.explanation: For domestic adoptions, qualified expenses paid before the year the adoption becomes final are claimed in the year the adoption is finalized. Expenses paid in the year of finalization or later are claimed in that year.
questions.tip: Adoption credit timing: Pre-finalization expenses claimed in year adoption finalizes.

questions.question: A business places a $1 million solar energy system in service in 2024. The base investment tax credit (ITC) is 6%, but can be increased to 30% by meeting which requirement?

options.B: Meeting prevailing wage and apprenticeship requirements

questions.explanation: The IRA provides a base 6% ITC for clean energy property. Meeting prevailing wage and apprenticeship requirements increases the credit 5x to 30%. Additional bonuses exist for domestic content, energy communities, and low-income.
questions.tip: Business energy ITC: 6% base → 30% with prevailing wage/apprenticeship.

questions.question: A married couple with AGI of $50,000 pays $8,000 in child care expenses for their two children under age 13 so both spouses can work. What is their child and dependent care credit?
questions.explanation: Maximum eligible expenses are $6,000 for two or more dependents. At $50,000 AGI, the credit percentage is 20%. Credit = $6,000 × 20% = $1,200. Even though they paid $8,000, expenses are capped.
questions.tip: Child care credit: Max $3K (1 child)/$6K (2+) × 20-35% based on AGI.

questions.question: A taxpayer invests $500,000 of capital gains into a qualified opportunity fund (QOF) in 2024. What tax benefit is available if the investment is held for 10 years?

options.B: Complete exclusion of appreciation in the QOF investment
options.C: Tax credit equal to 10% of investment
options.D: Both exclusion of appreciation and step-up in original gain basis

questions.explanation: For QOF investments held at least 10 years, appreciation in the QOF investment is permanently excluded from income. The basis step-ups (10% at 5 years, 15% at 7 years) expired for new investments but the 10-year appreciation exclusion remains.
questions.tip: QOZ 10-year hold: Appreciation in QOF investment permanently excluded.

questions.question: A single taxpayer with AGI of $20,000 contributes $1,500 to a traditional IRA. What is the retirement savings contribution credit (saver's credit)?
questions.explanation: For a single filer with AGI of $20,000 (2024), the saver's credit rate is 50% of contributions up to $2,000. Credit = $1,500 × 50% = $750. The maximum credit is $1,000 ($2,000 × 50%).
questions.tip: Saver's credit: 10-50% of up to $2,000 in retirement contributions based on AGI.

questions.question: The Employee Retention Credit (ERC) was available during the COVID-19 pandemic. Which statement about the ERC is correct?

options.A: The credit is still available for current wages
options.B: The credit was a refundable payroll tax credit
options.C: Only businesses with under 100 employees could qualify
options.D: The credit was limited to $5,000 total per employee

questions.explanation: The ERC was a refundable payroll tax credit (against employer's share of Social Security) for eligible employers during 2020-2021. It was worth up to $5,000 per employee for 2020 and up to $7,000 per quarter for 2021 (max $28,000).
questions.tip: ERC: Refundable payroll credit for COVID-impacted employers; ended 2021.

questions.question: When multiple nonrefundable credits apply, which credit is generally applied first?

options.D: Alternative minimum tax foreign tax credit

questions.explanation: Nonrefundable credits are applied in a specific order. Foreign tax credit is applied first (to the extent of limitation), followed by other personal credits (child tax credit, education credits, etc.), then general business credit, which can only reduce tax to tentative minimum tax.
questions.tip: Credit order: Foreign tax → Personal credits → General business credit.

questions.question: A student qualifies for both the American Opportunity Credit (AOC) and Lifetime Learning Credit (LLC). Which comparison is correct?

options.A: AOC has higher income phase-out thresholds than LLC
options.B: LLC provides a larger maximum credit than AOC
options.C: AOC is partially refundable; LLC is nonrefundable
options.D: LLC requires at least half-time enrollment; AOC does not

questions.explanation: The AOC is partially refundable (40% of credit, up to $1,000). The LLC is entirely nonrefundable. AOC maximum is $2,500; LLC maximum is $2,000. AOC requires at least half-time enrollment; LLC has no enrollment intensity requirement.
questions.tip: AOC: $2,500, 40% refundable, 4-year limit. LLC: $2,000, nonrefundable, unlimited years.

questions.question: An employer builds an on-site child care facility costing $200,000 and incurs $60,000 in annual operating expenses. What is the employer-provided child care credit?
questions.explanation: The Section 45F credit is 25% of qualified child care facility expenditures plus 10% of qualified child care resource and referral expenditures. Credit = ($200,000 × 25%) + ($60,000 × 10%) = $50,000 + $6,000 = $56,000, capped at $150,000.
questions.tip: Employer child care credit: 25% facility costs + 10% resource/referral costs (max $150K).

questions.question: A company has average QREs over the prior 3 years of $1 million and current year QREs of $1.5 million. Using the alternative simplified credit method, what is the R&D credit?
questions.explanation: The alternative simplified credit is 14% of QREs exceeding 50% of the average QREs for the 3 preceding years. Credit = 14% × ($1,500,000 - $500,000) = 14% × $1,000,000 = $140,000. If no QREs in prior years, credit is 6% of current QREs.
questions.tip: ASC: 14% × (current QREs - 50% of 3-year average QREs).

questions.question: A taxpayer has $200,000 worldwide taxable income, including $50,000 of foreign source income. U.S. tax before credits is $44,000. Foreign taxes paid were $15,000. What is the FTC limitation and allowable credit?
questions.explanation: FTC limitation = U.S. tax × (foreign source income / worldwide income) = $44,000 × ($50,000 / $200,000) = $44,000 × 25% = $11,000. The credit is limited to $11,000 even though $15,000 was paid. Excess $4,000 can be carried over.
questions.tip: FTC limit = U.S. tax × (foreign source income ÷ worldwide income).

questions.question: A 100-unit apartment building has eligible basis of $10 million. 60 units are set aside for low-income tenants at 60% of area median income. What is the qualified basis for LIHTC purposes?
questions.explanation: Qualified basis equals eligible basis multiplied by the applicable fraction (lesser of unit fraction or floor space fraction). With 60 of 100 units set aside, the applicable fraction is 60%. Qualified basis = $10M × 60% = $6 million.
questions.tip: LIHTC qualified basis = eligible basis × applicable fraction (low-income units/total units).

questions.question: A taxpayer has regular tax liability of $100,000 and tentative minimum tax of $85,000. What is the general business credit limitation?
questions.explanation: The general business credit cannot reduce regular tax liability below the tentative minimum tax (plus 25% of regular tax over $25,000 for some components). Here, the limitation is $100,000 - $85,000 = $15,000.
questions.tip: GBC limit: Regular tax - tentative minimum tax (simplified). Cannot push into AMT.

questions.question: A taxpayer in the 37% marginal bracket has $100,000 of qualified business income from an S corporation. The Section 199A deduction is $20,000. What is the effective tax benefit equivalent credit rate?
questions.explanation: The $20,000 deduction reduces taxable income, saving $20,000 × 37% = $7,400 in tax. As a percentage of the $100,000 QBI, this is a 7.4% effective rate. Unlike a credit, the benefit varies with marginal rate.
questions.tip: Deduction value = deduction × marginal rate. Section 199A: max 20% deduction × rate.

questions.question: A solar project placed in service in an energy community qualifies for the base 6% ITC plus prevailing wage/apprenticeship bonus (24%) and domestic content bonus (10%). What is the maximum ITC percentage?
questions.explanation: Maximum ITC: 6% base + 24% (wage/apprenticeship, 5x multiplier to 30%) + 10% domestic content + 10% energy community = 50%. Low-income bonuses can add more for certain projects. The base starts at 6% and wage/apprenticeship brings it to 30%, not additive to 6%.
questions.tip: ITC stacking: 30% (base + W&A) + 10% domestic + 10% energy community = 50% max typically.

questions.question: Under the Inflation Reduction Act, which clean energy credit can be transferred to an unrelated third party for cash?

options.C: Investment tax credit for business solar

questions.explanation: The IRA allows certain business energy credits (ITC, PTC, etc.) to be transferred to unrelated parties for cash. Personal/individual credits like the residential energy credit and personal clean vehicle credit cannot be transferred this way.
questions.tip: IRA transferability: Business energy credits only. Personal credits excluded.

questions.question: A taxpayer claimed a $100,000 investment tax credit on solar property placed in service in year 1. The property is sold in year 4. What amount of credit is recaptured?
questions.explanation: ITC recapture applies if property is disposed of within 5 years. Recapture decreases 20% per year. Year 4 disposition: 2 years remaining out of 5 = 40% recapture. No wait, the recapture is 20% per year after year 1. So by year 4: Years 2, 3, 4 passed = 60% vested, 40% recapture? Actually: Recapture = (5 - years held) / 5 × credit. (5-4)/5 = 20% recapture = $20,000.
questions.tip: ITC recapture: Credit × (5 - years held) / 5 if disposed within 5 years.

questions.question: A taxpayer has $50,000 of R&D credits and $30,000 of foreign tax credits. Regular tax is $60,000 and tentative minimum tax is $55,000. Which statement correctly describes the credit optimization?

options.A: All $80,000 of credits can be used
options.B: FTC is applied first, then R&D credit limited to $5,000
options.C: R&D credit is applied first as part of general business credit
options.D: Only FTC can be used; R&D credit is fully carried forward

questions.explanation: Foreign tax credit is applied first (limited by the FTC limitation formula). General business credit (including R&D) is then limited by the TMT barrier: $60,000 - $55,000 = $5,000. So FTC uses $30,000 (assuming sufficient limit), then only $5,000 of R&D credit can be used, with $45,000 carried over.
questions.tip: Credit order matters: FTC first, then GBC limited by TMT. Plan around limitations.
